Economist David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage explains how countries trade by focusing on specialization and trade's mutual benefits, regardless of absolute production efficiency. Opportunity cost, not absolute cost, determines comparative advantage in producing goods. The theory of comparative advantage, as proposed by economist David Ricardo, emphasizes that countries should specialize in goods they can produce relatively well and trade for goods they produce less efficiently. This theory focuses on opportunity cost rather than absolute production costs. Modern economic theories have further developed the concept of comparative advantage to explain complex trade patterns in the 21st century, including global value chains and digital trade.
